However, the authority over the angels that appeared for Adam, peace be upon him, through his exclusive knowledge of all the Names, had not appeared for him.

Thus, on that Day, everyone—including the angels and mankind, from Adam downwards—is in need of him to open the door of intercession and to manifest the high status he holds with Allah, since the Divine Compulsion (al-Qahr al-Ilāhī) and the Greatest Majesty (al-Jabarūt al-A'zam) had silenced everyone. This station is like the station of Adam, peace be upon him, and greater, on a day when the need is intense, coupled with the mention of the Divine Wrath (al-Ghadab al-Ilāhī) in which The Real manifests on that Day. Such an attribute did not manifest in the affair of Adam. The totality of these events indicates his immense status (PBUH), as he stepped forward to supplicate The Real concerning the request despite this Attribute of Divine Wrath.

### The Theophany of The Real on the Day of Resurrection in the Lowest Form

The Real, Glory be to Him, answers him. The Balances are set up, the scrolls are spread, the Bridge is erected, and intercession begins. The angels intercede first, then the Prophets, then the believers. And the Most Merciful of the Merciful remains.

Here there is a great detail that would prolong the discussion, for it is a momentous station. However, The Real manifests on that Day and says that every nation should follow what they used to worship, until only this nation remains, including its hypocrites. The Real manifests to them in the lowest form of the forms in which He had manifested to them before. He says, "I am your Lord." They say, "We seek refuge in Allah from you. We are waiting until our Lord comes to us." He, Glorified and Exalted, says to them, "Is there a sign between you and Him by which you recognize Him?" They say, "Yes." He transforms for them into the form in which they recognized Him by that sign. They say, "You are our Lord."

He commands them to prostrate. No one who used to prostrate to Allah remains but that he prostrates. But whoever used to prostrate out of hypocrisy and show (Riyā') has his back made into a layer of copper; whenever he tries to prostrate, he falls backward onto his nape. This is His saying: <<يَوْمَ يُكْشَفُ عَنْ سَاقٍ وَيُدْعَوْنَ إِلَى السُّجُودِ فَلَا يَسْتَطِيعُونَ ... وَقَدْ كَانُوا يُدْعَوْنَ إِلَى السُّجُودِ وَهُمْ سَالِمُونَ>> (The Day the Shin will be uncovered, and they will be invited to prostration but will not be able... And they had been invited to prostration while they were sound)—meaning, in the world.

The Shin (Sāq) that is uncovered for them is an expression for a great matter of the horrors of the Day of Resurrection. The Arabs say, "The war uncovered its shin," when the war intensified and its affair became momentous. Likewise, <<الْتَفَّتِ السَّاقُ بِالسَّاقِ>> (And the leg is joined with the leg) means that the horrors and momentous affairs entered into one another on the Day of Resurrection.

### Intellectual Monotheism and Legal Monotheism and Entry into Paradise

When intercession has taken place, and no legal believer (Mu'min Shar'ī) remains in the Fire at all, nor anyone who performed a prescribed deed (Amal Mashrū') as prescribed by the tongue of a Prophet, even if it was <<مِثْقَالَ حَبَّةٍ مِنْ خَرْدَلٍ>> (the weight of a mustard seed) or smaller, but that he has emerged through the intercession of the Prophets and believers—there remain the people of Monotheism (Ahl al-Tawhīd) who knew Monotheism through rational proofs ('Adilla al-'Aqliyya) and did not associate anything with Allah, but who did not believe with legal faith (Īmān Shar'ī) and never performed any good deed at all by following a Prophet. They did not possess an atom of faith or less.

These are the ones whom the Most Merciful of the Merciful brings out. His saying, "And they never performed any good deed at all," means a prescribed deed, as prescribed by law. And there is no greater good deed than faith (Īmān), which they did not perform.

This is the Hadith of 'Uthmān ibn 'Affān in *Sahīh Muslim ibn al-Hajjāj*: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Whoever dies while he *knows* (and he did not say *believes*) that there is no god but Allah, enters Paradise."

He did not say *says*, but singled out *knowledge* ('Ilm). It is for these people that Allah’s providence precedes in the Fire, for the Fire itself does not accept the eternal dwelling of a monotheist (Muwahhid) in any form whatsoever. The most perfect form of this is faith based on knowledge, combining knowledge and faith.

If you say, "But Iblīs knows that Allah is One," we say, "You speak truly, but he was the first to institute polytheism (Shirk), so he bears the sin of the polytheists, and their sin is that they do not leave the Fire." This is if it is established that he died a monotheist. But how do you know? Perhaps he died a polytheist due to a doubt that occurred to him in his contemplation. We have previously discussed this issue in past chapters. Iblīs is not leaving the Fire. Allah knows which of these was the case.

Here there is much knowledge, and its inclusion would be lengthy and take us away from the goal of brevity. Nevertheless, we must mention a summary of every famous station (Mawṭin) of the Resurrection, such as the Presentation ('Ard), the Taking of the Books, the Balance (Mīzān), the Bridge (Sirāt), the Heights (A'rāf), the Slaughter of Death (Dhabh al-Mawt), and the Feast (Ma'duba) that takes place in the field of Paradise. These are seven stations and no more. They are the mothers (Ummāhāt) of the seven gates of the Fire and the seven gates of Paradise. The eighth gate is the Gate of Vision (Jannat al-Ru'ya), which is the closed gate in the Fire—the Gate of the Veil (Bāb al-Hijāb)—which will never be opened, for the people of the Fire are veiled from their Lord.

### Continuation: The Seven Primary Stations on the Day of Resurrection

### The First Station: The Presentation (Al-'Ard)

It is narrated in the tradition that the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) was asked about Allah’s saying: <<فَسَوْفَ يُحَاسَبُ حِسَابًا يَسِيرًا>> (He will soon be reckoned with an easy reckoning). He said: "That is the Presentation, O 'Ā'isha. Whoever is questioned in detail about the reckoning will be tormented."

It is like the presentation of an army—meaning, the presentation of deeds—not because they are the attire of the people of the Standing. Allah is the Sovereign, so <<يُعْرَفُ الْمُجْرِمُونَ بِسِيمَاهُمْ>> (the criminals will be known by their marks), just as soldiers here are known by their uniform.

### The Second Station: The Books (Al-Kutub)

Allah the Exalted said: <<اقْرَأْ كِتَابَكَ كَفَى بِنَفْسِكَ الْيَوْمَ عَلَيْكَ حَسِيبًا>> (Read your book. Sufficient is yourself against you this Day as a reckoner). And He said: <<فَأَمَّا مَنْ أُوتِيَ كِتَابَهُ بِيَمِينِهِ>> (As for he who is given his book in his right hand), who is the fortunate believer, and <<وَأَمَّا مَنْ أُوتِيَ كِتَابَهُ بِشِمَالِهِ>> (But as for he who is given his book in his left hand), who is the hypocrite (Munāfiq). The disbeliever (Kāfir) has no book [of deeds]. The hypocrite was stripped of faith but not of Islam.

It is said concerning the hypocrite: <<إِنَّهُ كَانَ لَا يُؤْمِنُ بِاللَّهِ الْعَظِيمِ>> (Indeed, he did not believe in Allah, the Magnificent). This includes the atheist (Mu'attil), the polytheist (Mushrik), and the one arrogant toward Allah. It does not address Islam, for the hypocrite outwardly submits to protect his wealth, family, and blood, while inwardly he is one of these three. We say that this verse encompasses the three because His saying <<لَا يُؤْمِنُ بِاللَّهِ الْعَظِيمِ>> means he does not affirm Allah. Those who do not affirm Allah are two groups: a group that does not affirm the existence of Allah (the atheists), and a group that does not affirm the Oneness of Allah (the polytheists). His saying *Al-Azīm* (The Magnificent) in this verse includes the one arrogant toward Allah, for if he believed in the Magnificence of Allah that is due to the one named Allah, he would not be arrogant toward Him. These three, along with the hypocrite who is distinguished from them by a specific description, are the people of the Fire who belong there.

As for <<وَأَمَّا مَنْ أُوتِيَ كِتَابَهُ وَرَاءَ ظَهْرِهِ>> (But as for he who is given his book behind his back), these are those who were given the Scripture (Kitāb), but <<فَنَبَذُوهُ وَرَاءَ ظُهُورِهِمْ وَاشْتَرَوْا بِهِ ثَمَنًا قَلِيلًا>> (cast it behind their backs and exchanged it for a small price). When the Day of Resurrection comes, it will be said to him, "Take it from behind your back," meaning from the place where you cast it in your worldly life. This is their revealed Scripture, not the book of deeds. When he cast it behind his back, <<ظَنَّ أَنْ لَنْ يَحُورَ>> (he thought that he would never return), meaning he was certain. The poet said:

> I said to them, "Be certain of two thousand armored men."

It is mentioned in the *Sahīh* that Allah says to him on the Day of Resurrection, "Did you think that you would meet Me?"

And Allah the Exalted said: <<وَذَلِكُمْ ظَنُّكُمُ الَّذِي ظَنَنْتُمْ بِرَبِّكُمْ أَرْدَاكُمْ>> (And that was your assumption which you assumed about your Lord. It has ruined you).

### The Third Station: The Balances (Al-Mawāzīn)

The Balances are set up to weigh the deeds. The scrolls containing what they did are placed in them. The last thing placed in the Balance is a person’s saying, *Al-Hamdulillah* (Praise be to Allah). For this reason,

The Prophet (PBUH) said: "Praise be to Allah fills the Balance."

All the deeds of the servants are cast into the Balance except the phrase *Lā ilāha illā Allāh* (There is no god but Allah). A single utterance of praise (Tahmīda) remains to fill it, and when it is placed, the Balance is filled by it. The scale of every person is commensurate with his deeds, without increase or decrease. Every remembrance and deed enters the Balance except *Lā ilāha illā Allāh*, as we said.

The reason for this is that every good deed has an opposite counterpart. This good deed is placed in its balance. But *Lā ilāha illā Allāh* is only countered by polytheism (Shirk). Monotheism and polytheism cannot coexist in anyone’s Balance, because if he says *Lā ilāha illā Allāh* believing in it, he has not committed polytheism; and if he commits polytheism, he has not believed in *Lā ilāha illā Allāh*. Since it is impossible for them to be combined, the phrase *Lā ilāha illā Allāh* has nothing to counterbalance it in the other scale, and nothing outweighs it. Therefore, it does not enter the Balance.

As for the polytheists, <<فَلَا نُقِيمُ لَهُمْ يَوْمَ الْقِيَامَةِ وَزْنًا>> (We will not assign to them on the Day of Resurrection any weight), meaning they have no value, and no deed will be weighed for them, nor for those like them who denied the meeting with Allah and disbelieved in His signs. The good deeds of the polytheist are nullified, so their evil deeds have nothing to counterbalance them. <<فَلَا نُقِيمُ لَهُمْ يَوْمَ الْقِيَامَةِ وَزْنًا>>.

As for the person of the Scrolls (Sijillāt), he is a person who never performed any good deed at all, except that one day he uttered the phrase *Lā ilāha illā Allāh* sincerely. It is placed for him opposite ninety-nine scrolls of evil deeds, each scroll being as vast as the distance between the East and the West. This is because he has no other good deed. His scale outweighs all the scrolls, and the scrolls fly up. People are astonished by this.

Only the deeds of the physical limbs (Jawārih)—their good and evil: hearing, sight, tongue, hand, stomach, private parts, and leg—enter the sensible Balance. As for the inner deeds, they do not enter the sensible Balance, but justice is established for them in the judicial, metaphysical Balance (al-Mīzān al-Hukmī al-Ma'nawī), where the sensible is countered by the sensible, and the spiritual by the spiritual. Everything is countered by its like. Therefore, deeds are weighed in terms of how they are written.

### The Fourth Station: The Bridge (Al-Sirāt)

This is the prescribed Path (Sirāt) which was a spiritual meaning here, but will be erected there as a sensible, physical reality. Allah says to us: <<وَأَنَّ هَذَا صِرَاطِي مُسْتَقِيمًا فَاتَّبِعُوهُ وَلَا تَتَّبِعُوا السُّبُلَ فَتَفَرَّقَ بِكُمْ عَنْ سَبِيلِهِ>> (And indeed, this is My path, straight, so follow it and do not follow [other] ways, for they will separate you from His way). When the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) recited this verse, he drew a line and drew lines on its sides, thus:

[Diagram implied: a straight line with lines branching off]

This is the path of Monotheism (Tawhīd), its requirements, and its rights.

The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "I have been commanded to fight people until they say, 'There is no god but Allah.' If they say it, they have protected their blood and wealth from me, except by the right of Islam, and their reckoning is with Allah."

[The rest of the Hadith will follow in the chapter on Paradise.]

He intended by His saying, "and their reckoning is upon Allah," that none knows whether they spoke it believing in it except Allah. Thus, the polytheist (المشرك) has no footing (قدم) upon the Bridge of Unity (صراط التوحيد), but he does have a footing upon the Bridge of Existence (صراط الوجود). The denier (المعطل) has no footing upon the Bridge of Existence. The polytheist did not affirm Allah's Unity here [in this life], so he proceeds from the Station [of Judgment] to the Fire along with the deniers. Who are the people of the Fire who truly belong there, except the hypocrites (المنافقين)? They must look upon Paradise and the bliss within it, and thus they covet it. That is their portion of the bliss of the Gardens, and then they are turned away to the Fire. This is part of Allah’s Justice, for they are recompensed according to their deeds.

The group that is not eternally abiding in the Fire is held, questioned, and tormented upon the Bridge (الصراط). The Bridge is situated over the surface of Hell (جهنم), submerged within it, and the hooks (الكلاليب) upon it are what Allah uses to hold them there. Since the Bridge is in the Fire, and there is no path to Paradise except across it, Allah the Exalted said: <<وَإِنْ مِنْكُمْ إِلَّا وَارِدُهَا كَانَ عَلَى رَبِّكَ حَتْمًا مَقْضِيًّا>> (And there is none of you except that he will reach it. This is upon your Lord an inevitability decreed) [Q. 19:71]. Whoever understands the meaning of this saying knows the true location of Hell. Had the Prophet (PBUH) stated it when he was asked about it, I would have stated it. He only remained silent about it and said, in response, "It is in the Knowledge of Allah," by a Divine command, for <<وَمَا يَنْطِقُ عَنِ الْهَوَى>> (nor does he speak from [his own] inclination) [Q. 53:3]. Since this is not a matter of this world, our silence concerning it is proper etiquette (الأدب).

It has been reported concerning the description of the Bridge that it is finer than a hair and sharper than a sword. Likewise is the science of the Sacred Law (الشريعة) in this world: one does not know the exact face of the Truth (وجه الحق) in a given legal issue as it is with Allah, nor precisely which of the jurists (المجتهدين) is correct. For this reason, we are obligated to follow the preponderance of probability (غلبات الظنون) after exerting effort in seeking the evidence, except in cases of widely transmitted reports (المتواتر) or known, sound solitary reports (خبر الواحد الصحيح المعلوم). Although the widely transmitted report provides certainty (العلم), the certainty derived from it is only the certainty that the Prophet (PBUH) spoke or acted upon that specific wording. What we seek through knowledge (العلم) is the understanding derived from that saying or action, so that one may rule on the issue with absolute certainty (القطع). This certainty is only reached through an explicit, widely transmitted text (النص الصريح المتواتر), which is rarely found, such as His saying, the Exalted: <<تِلْكَ عَشَرَةٌ كَامِلَةٌ>> (That is ten complete) [Q. 2:196], specifically concerning the number ten. Thus, the ruling of the Sacred Law is sharper than a sword and finer than a hair in this world. The one who is correct in the ruling is one, though not specifically identified, yet all are correct in receiving the reward. The Sacred Law here is the Straight Path (الصراط المستقيم). One continuously says in every unit (ركعة) of the prayer: <<اهْدِنَا الصِّرَاطَ الْمُسْتَقِيمَ>> (Guide us to the Straight Path) [Q. 1:6]. It is sharper than a sword and finer than a hair. Its manifestation in the Hereafter is a tangible reality, clearer and more evident than its manifestation in this world, except for those who call to Allah upon insight (بصيرة), like the Messenger and his followers. Allah joins them to the rank of the Prophets in calling <<إِلَى اللَّهِ عَلَى بَصِيرَةٍ>> (to Allah upon insight), meaning upon knowledge (علم) and unveiling (كشف).

It has been reported in a narration that the surface of the Bridge appears on the Day of Resurrection to the eyes according to the measure of the light (نور) of those passing over it. Thus, it is narrow for some people and wide for others. This narration is confirmed by His saying, the Exalted: <<نُورُهُمْ يَسْعَى بَيْنَ أَيْدِيهِمْ وَبِأَيْمَانِهِمْ>> (Their light will proceed before them and on their right) [Q. 66:8]. The proceeding (السعي) is walking, and there is no path there except the Bridge. He only mentioned "on their right" (بِأَيْمَانِهِمْ) because the believer in the Hereafter has no left side, just as the people of the Fire have no right side. This is some of the description of what occurs on the Bridge.

As for the hooks (الكلاليب), grappling irons (الخطاطيف), and thorns (الحسك), as we mentioned, they are the forms of the deeds of the children of Adam. Their deeds hold them upon the Bridge, so they neither advance toward Paradise nor fall into the Fire until intercession (الشفاعة) and Divine Providence (العناية الإلهية) reach them, as we have established. Whoever overlooks [the faults of others] here, Allah will overlook his faults there. Whoever grants respite to one in difficulty, Allah will grant him respite. Whoever pardons, Allah will pardon him. Whoever insists on receiving his full right from His servants here, Allah will insist on receiving His full right from him there. Whoever is harsh toward this Community (الأمة), Allah will be harsh toward him. Indeed, these are your deeds returned to you, so adhere to noble character (مكارم الأخلاق). For tomorrow, Allah will deal with you according to how you dealt with His servants, whatever happened and whoever they were.

**The Fifth Station: Al-A'raf (The Heights)**

As for Al-A'raf, it is a wall (سور) between Paradise and the Fire. <<بَاطِنُهُ فِيهِ الرَّحْمَةُ>> (Its interior contains mercy) [Q. 57:13], which is the side facing Paradise, and <<وَظَاهِرُهُ مِنْ قِبَلِهِ الْعَذَابُ>> (and its exterior, before it, is torment) [Q. 57:13], which is the side facing the Fire. Those whose scales of deeds are equally balanced stand upon it. They look toward the Fire and they look toward Paradise, having no preponderance that would admit them to either abode. When they are called to prostrate (السجود)—which is the only remaining obligation (تكليف) on the Day of Resurrection—they prostrate, and their scale of good deeds (حسناتهم) tips, so they enter Paradise. They had been looking toward the Fire because of their evil deeds (سيئات) and looking toward Paradise because of their good deeds, and they see Allah’s Mercy, so they covet it. The reason for their coveting is also that they are among the people of "There is no god but Allah" (لا إله إلا الله), yet they do not see it in their scale. They know that <<إِنَّ اللَّهَ لَا يَظْلِمُ مِثْقَالَ ذَرَّةٍ>> (Indeed, Allah wrongs not even the weight of an atom) [Q. 4:40]. If an atom had been added to either scale, it would have tipped it, because they are in a state of perfect equilibrium. Thus, they covet Allah’s Generosity and Justice, knowing that the phrase *la ilaha illa Allah* must necessarily have a special providence (عناية) for its speaker, the effect of which must manifest upon them.

The Mighty and Majestic says concerning them: <<وَعَلَى الْأَعْرَافِ رِجَالٌ يَعْرِفُونَ كُلًّا بِسِيمَاهُمْ وَنَادَوْا أَصْحَابَ الْجَنَّةِ أَنْ سَلَامٌ عَلَيْكُمْ لَمْ يَدْخُلُوهَا وَهُمْ يَطْمَعُونَ>> (And on the Heights will be men who recognize all by their marks. And they will call to the companions of Paradise, "Peace be upon you." They have not entered it, but they long [for it]) [Q. 7:46]. Likewise, they call out when <<إِذَا صُرِفَتْ أَبْصَارُهُمْ تِلْقَاءَ أَصْحَابِ النَّارِ قَالُوا رَبَّنَا لَا تَجْعَلْنَا مَعَ الْقَوْمِ الظَّالِمِينَ>> (their eyes are turned toward the companions of the Fire, they say, "Our Lord, do not place us with the wrongdoing people") [Q. 7:47]. The wrongdoing (الظلم) here is polytheism (الشرك) and nothing else.

**The Sixth Station: The Slaughter of Death**

Although Death (الموت) is a relative concept (نسبة), Allah will manifest it on the Day of Resurrection in the form of a speckled ram (كبش أملح). A caller will cry out, "O people of Paradise!" and they will crane their necks. And a caller will cry out, "O people of the Fire!" and they will crane their necks. At that time, only those who truly belong to the Fire will be in it. It will be said to both groups, "Do you recognize this?"—and it will be standing between Paradise and the Fire. They will say, "It is Death." Then John (Yahya), peace be upon him, will come with a knife in his hand, lay it down, and slaughter it. A caller will then proclaim: "O people of Paradise, Eternity (خلود) with no death! And O people of the Fire, Eternity with no death!" That is the Day of Regret (يَوْمَ الْحَسْرَةِ).

As for the people of Paradise, when they see Death, they rejoice greatly at its sight and say to it, "May Allah bless you for us! You have delivered us from the misery of the world, and you were the best arrival for us and the best gift (تحفة) The Real (الحق) presented to us." For the Prophet (PBUH) said: "Death is the gift of the believer." As for the people of the Fire, when they see it, they are terrified of it and say to it, "You were the worst arrival for us, for you stood between us and the goodness and tranquility we were in." Then they say to it, "Perhaps you will kill us so we may rest from what we are in."

It is only called the Day of Regret (يوم الحسرة) because it reveals (حسر) to all the quality of permanent Eternity (الخلود الدائم) for both groups. Then the gates of the Fire are sealed with a sealing after which there is no opening. The Fire collapses upon its inhabitants, and parts of it enter into other parts to intensify the compression (انضغاط) of its people within it. Its bottom returns to its top, and its top to its bottom. You will see the humans and the devils within it like pieces of meat in a pot, since beneath it is the mighty Fire, boiling <<كَغْلِي الْحَمِيمِ>> (like the boiling of scalding water) [Q. 44:46]. It rotates those within it, high and low. <<كُلَّمَا خَبَتْ زِدْنَاهُمْ سَعِيرًا>> (Whenever it subsides, We will increase them in [the blaze of] fire) [Q. 17:97] by replacing their skins.

**The Seventh Station: The Feast**

This is the King’s feast (مأدبة) for the people of Paradise. At that time, the people of the Fire gather in a place of lamentation (مندبة). Thus, the people of Paradise are at the feast (مأدب), and the people of the Fire are in lamentation (منادب). Their food at that feast is the excess of the liver of the Nun (whale/fish). The ground of the gathering place is white *durmaka* (fine flour) like a flat loaf. The spleen (الطحال) of the Ox (الثور) is brought forth for the people of the Fire.

The people of Paradise eat from the excess of the liver of the Nun, which is a marine, aquatic creature, belonging to the element of life (عنصر الحياة) appropriate for Paradise. The liver is the house of blood, and it is the house of life. Life is hot and moist. The vapor of that blood is the soul (النفس), expressed as the animal spirit (الروح الحيواني) by which the body lives. This is a glad tiding for the people of Paradise concerning the permanence of their life.

As for the spleen (الطحال) in the animal body, it is the house of impurities (الأوساخ), for the body’s impurities gather in it, specifically the corrupted blood that the liver gives off. This is given to the people of the Fire to eat. It comes from the Ox (الثور), which is a terrestrial animal whose nature is cold and dry. Hell (جهنم) is in the form of a buffalo (جاموس). The spleen of the Ox is thus most appropriate as nourishment for the people of the Fire. Due to the bloodiness (الدمية) in the spleen, the people of the Fire do not die, but due to the impurities of the body and the painful corrupted blood within it, they neither live nor enjoy bliss. Eating it bequeaths them sickness and illness.

Then the people of Paradise enter Paradise, <<مَا هُمْ مِنْهَا بِمُخْرَجِينَ>> (and they will not be removed from it) [Q. 15:48]. And Allah <<يَقُولُ الْحَقَّ وَهُوَ يَهْدِي السَّبِيلَ>> (speaks the Truth, and He guides to the way) [Q. 33:4].

End of the Twenty-Eighth Part.
